taxonomicnotes: McClelland (1845) described Ctenops nobilis from northern Bengal.
rationale: The species is widely distributed but it is a naturally scarce species.  It is a mouth-brooder and has naturally large eggs, a specialised reproductive strategy, and potentially more impacted by disturbance.  The population has declined in Assam (due to habitat loss), but there is no information on the population or its habitat in other parts of its range.  The species appears to be threatened in part of its range, and the same is inferred in the rest of its range as the habits and uses of people are similar.  Ctenops nobilis is assessed as Near Threatened as there is insufficient information to determine its population declines in the wild, however the status must be reevaluated after urgent studies on the species' distribution, biology, use, trends and threats reveal more information.  The species is likely to be more threatened than what is assessed currently.
evaluator: Britz, R., Allen, D.J., Datta, N.C., Dey, S.C., Vishwanath, W. & Jha, B.R.
